text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: In order to keep you on this study, uh, from the side effect perspective, we’re going to need to temporarily stop the medication again, unfortunately- Because of this hemoglobin being eight point nine. Okay? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, it’s very likely that when you come back on September fifth, your hemoglobin will be above nine, hopefully, above ten, it will recover some, in other words, uh, and then given that the hemoglobin has improved, we can put you back on the medication, but it will be at the two-hundred milligram dose. It’ll be a second level of dose reduction. Okay? Patient: Hum. Doctor: I don’t think you’ll need to go lower than that. Okay? But I think the two-fifty in terms of the anemia, uh, it did cause the same problem, again, to a lesser degree, but it did still cause the same problem. Uh, so my preference, if you want to remain on the study, which I think is reasonable, would be as of today to ask you to stop the medication until you come back and see us on September the fifth. And on that day, what we’re probably going to recommend, provided that your hemoglobin has increased again, preferably above ten, but at least above nine, is we’re going to put you back on the second dose level reduction which will be two hundred milligrams per day. Patient: Hum. Okay. Family Member: So between now and September fifth, a week-? Doctor: That’s, that’s two weeks. Yeah. Family Member: Does he go in for another blood transfusion or are you expecting the hemoglobin to increase pretty much on its own as he regulates without the medication? Doctor: One idea would be to check a hemoglobin level at a local laboratory, uh, one week from now just to see where we are at. And if it has made significant progress on its own, we can skip the blood transfusion. And if it looks like it’s only gone up like one-tenth of a point, then we can perhaps schedule a blood transfusion before September fifth. So if you agree to that, I can give you, uh, a prescription for a complete blood count. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Okay? I think that’s really critical for the first few weeks. Family Member: Okay. Great. Doctor: Slowly both of us will get a good sense of how you’re tolerating this, how things are going, and, obviously, if it’s working, we keep going with it. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: If it’s not helping you, I’m going to stop the treatment. No matter which treatment you’re on. If it’s not working, not helping you, I will tell you that, and I will take you off of the stuff. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: But the good news is there are a number of different treatments. Uh, you know, this one is worth a try, but otherwise there are hormonal pills or other really effective things, too, that we can use outside of the study. Okay? text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because most of what we’re looking for is how you feel. Oh, I’m having nausea. No. I’m not having nausea. Oh, this was a cakewalk. Oh, my fingers aren’t numb. So then we can sort of compare what blood test and symptoms are for those who actually get the vitamin C versus those who don’t. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you have a fifty-fifty chance that you’re going to get the real stuff. Huh, you know, there is some flexibility. They want you here at least twice a week. But you know, if you’re going to go on holiday or something, you know, we can switch it. Huh, so far we know that giving high doses of vitamin C is safe. Huh, we haven’t seen many real extra side effects. But we don’t know the end of the answer. Does it help with side effects? Does it help activity? Or is there no difference? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so you would be potentially eligible for that. Huh, if you do a clinical trial, it does slow down a little bit when we get started. Okay? Huh, because we would first want to check your insurance company that they will pay for the clinical trial. You’re not on Medicare yet. You’re not sixty-five. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, so we’d have to check with your insurance. Do they cover clinical trials, if you’re interested? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, if they are. Then in the forms that we give them and give you, it tells them, huh, what they’re paying for, and it tells you what we’re going to pay for. So definitely the dummy vitamin C or the real vitamin C we pay for because that’s experimental. Your insurance company may have to pay for the time in the chair to get the medicine. Okay? Huh, if you have to pay five dollars every time you come into this building, huh, this study could cost you more money because you’re here more often. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, but if you don’t have a copay for visits, then that’s, you know. So there are some hidden costs. You know? If you’re coming in more often and you have to pay for parking and, you know, those sorts of things, huh, we do have the ability for some of our studies to pay for your parking. We do. Or even if you need a ride here, there’s a group of, do you live in the city? Patient: Um hum.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it’s in a location which is classical and typical for where prostate cancer can typically spread. Patient: Okay then that’s - where is it? Where did you say it went? Doctor: I have to remind myself which side it’s on. It’s on the abdominal - it’s in the abdomen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s too deep to feel, so it’s internal, inside the abdomen. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s on the uh - it’s called the left iliac lymph node. So the left iliac lymph node is basically um where the blood vessel called the aorta splits up into the two iliac arteries. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then there are lymph nodes on each side. So I would say if I, if I could go through your abdomen like three inches, I’d hit it; it’s on the left side. Patient: Now I did have uh a gist and I had that surgery July the thirteenth. I remember that was in the stomach. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So is it in somewhere in comparison…? text: Patient: Okay will it get curlier? Doctor: It got curlier because the old chemotherapy’s outta your system. Patient: Yeah. (Pause5sec) Family Member: Well, so, if I was your dad, what would you do? Let him have to decide? Doctor: Yeah. I, um, I don’t know – I’ve never made a decision for ya. Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know, the issue is sort of your sense of what you do to your children, brother, what you want to do. You’re physically well enough. You, you know, if you can think about those things, I think a clinical trial makes a lot of sense. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Or my sense is the other thing is, you know, if time was short, I probably would sort of step back and sort of just focus on, you know, good days. Um. So I would sit there on the fence. I’m not ready to give up on myself. I wanna try something versus -- hhh this has all been too much. (Pause4sec) Patient: If it, it, it extends my, my time that I have to wait for a real cure then maybe it’s worth it. Doctor: Well, that reality is pretty slim. You know, we’ve been working on this awhile, and I’m not sure that a cure is gonna just pop up in the next six months, nine months. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And again, we often, er, don’t have drugs that resurrect people. Uh. You can hope. I hope and pray as well. Uh. The reality is, you know, you can keep pluggin’ along. Uh, so I think you’re eligible because you’re physically well enough to get through this.

text: Patient: Uh (relation) Doctor: So it’s not direct. It would be well I’m super tired or my stomach doesn’t feel good then I eat and drink less. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then you’re dehydrated and your - and organ like kidney or liver takes a hit. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Gotcha. Doctor: That’s the problem. Patient: I’m not eating less. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I do feel that I’m eating better… Um… Family Member: Mhmm. Doctor: Yeah because you got a week off.

text: Patient: That’s what I’m like, that’s what I was trying to tell you. That’s the way he didn’t know what I take. He said you still taking the prednisone Doctor: So you need a new script? Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
